org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: US DEPARTMENT OF LABOR IMMIGRATION SERVICE DISTRICT NO.16
REPLYING REFER TO NO. 37012/600
DISTRICT HEADQUARTERS U.S. COMMISSIONER OF IMMIGRATION SEATTLE, WASH.
Commissioner General of Immigration, Washington, D.C.

Referring to your file 98793/14, the cause of JACK MATTHEWS, alias YAN MATVEYEFF, I beg to advise that I have been informed that the alien has received a letter from his brother, reading in part, and in effect as follows,
"South Russia, that is the place where you want to go, or any part of Russia; even Siberia, Vlsdivostok. Your birthplace is Podolska Province of Ukrania, Kaminetz, Podolska."
Commissioner.
SEATTLE CENTRAL LABOR COUNCIL "ONE FOR ALL AND ALL FOR ONE" SEATTLE, WASH.
Mr. W.W. Husband, Commissioner General of Immigration, Washington, D.C.
Dear Sir:
In reply to your letter of the 14th inst. I beg to you that you are, I believe, misinformed about certain very vital matters in the Jack Matthews case.

Matthews is not now serving a sentence in either the U.S. penintentiart or the county jail but, on the other hand, is held a prisoner in the county jail solely on the Department's deportation order of February 19th, 1921, and has been so held ever since April 4th, 1921, the date of his release from McNeils Island.

The sole reason for this long delay in accomplishing his deportation is, as I am informed, the governments inability to secure passpart to Ukrania, the country of his nativity, and the country to which he was ordered deported.

In different letters coming from your department, you have sometimes referred to Roumaina or Poland as the country of deportation. These are errors. The country is Ukrania, and having found that this is the place of his nativity and having ordered him deported to this place, of course the department cannot now modify eitherthe finding or the order, and any attempt to do so would be clearly arbitrary and would establish a basis for discharge on habeas corpus.
I am lead to believe that it will be impossible to secure the passport to Ukrania; in fact I understand that this government has no diplomatic relations with the goverment

of Ukrania. Under these circumstances it seems to me that the time has already arrived for the application of the principle declared in both your letters of the 30th ultimo and 14th inst, viz., that if arrangements cannot be made for his deportation he should be released, temporarily at least on his personal recognizance.

I trust that you will forthwith make an order authorizing such a release. Manifestly, Matthews cannot submit to perpetual imprisonment in the county jail on account of your inability to procure passports necessary to his deportation; and unless you consent to his release in the manner suggested we will be compelled to apply for a writ of habeas corpus.
Yours very truly, Geo. F. Vanderveer.
Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Washington.

Referring to the case of John Matthews, your No.37012/600, you are advised that the Bureau is in receipt of information from the Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, N.Y.H., to th effect that he unable to secure a Polish passport for this man. It appears to the Bureau that this alien is really a a native and subject of Ukrania and there is transmitted herewith an application for Ukrainian passport, and it is requested that you have this filled in and return to the Bureau together with a copy of the hearing in this case, when an effort will be made to secure a Ukranian passport.
Assistant Commissioner General. (Signed) ALFRED HAMPTON JUL 27 1921 MAIL AND FILED
US DEPARTMENT OF LABOR IMMIGRATION SERVICE
OFFICE OF COMMISSIONER OF IMMIGRATION ELLIS ISLAND NEW YORK HARBOR, N.Y.
July 22nd, 1921
Commissioner- General of Immigration, Washington D.C.,
Please refer to Bureau file 54904/149 relating to the case of Jack Matthews, or John Matthews, alias Yan Matveyeff.

The Polish Coneul in New York refuses to issue a passport for this alien, on the ground that no satisfactory information has been furnished as to the alien's place of birth. It will be noted from the enclosed correspondence that no exact information is available as to the place of alien's birth. It appears also from the record of hearing, that he may be a native of Ukrainia.

Enclosed correspondence is therefore, referred to the Bureau, in order that an effort may be made to secure a passport from te Ukrainian representative or such other action as you may use fit to take.
Harry R. In charge B.S.I. & Appeals
